author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What’s after Omicron?
description: Carl Zimmer addresses speculation about the Omicron surge and its aftermath.
content: The Omicron variant continues to shatter records in the U.S. Yesterday, the country recorded a staggering 885,000 cases, and experts say the peak is still weeks away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: With a Pardon, Homer Plessy’s Record Is Clear, but a Painful Legacy Endures
description: He boarded a whites-only train with the hope of undoing racist laws. Instead, his arrest led to a Supreme Court decision that upheld the “separate but equal” doctrine used to justify segregation.
content: Descendants of Homer Plessy like to say that he was a civil rights activist before most people in Louisiana were familiar with such a term. In 1892, Plessy, a racially mixed shoemaker, boarded a whites-only train car in New Orleans, well aware that he was breaking the law and would most likely be arrested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Attorney General Vows to Pursue Jan. 6 Inquiry ‘at Any Level’
description: The remarks came as Merrick B. Garland faces pressure from Democrats to more aggressively investigate any role that Donald J. Trump and his allies may have played in encouraging the violence.
content: WASHINGTON — Facing criticism from Democrats and a few Republicans to hold former President Donald J. Trump accountable for his role in inspiring the riot at the Capitol, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland vowed on Wednesday that the Justice Department would pursue wrongdoing “at any level,” saying he would defend democratic institutions from attack and threats of violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Was Norman Mailer Canceled? His Publishers Say No.
description: The independent press Skyhorse acquired a new book by the late writer after Random House, his longtime publisher, declined to make an offer.
content: Last year, in the wake of growing partisan division in America and the Jan. 6 riots, friends and strangers kept asking John Buffalo Mailer what his father, who died in 2007, would make of this moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Is it time for big in-person events again? Organizers are divided.
description: Some big events are delaying their return to in-person gatherings, but the organizers of CES, the Winter Olympics and the Australian Open have decided it’s time to gather in person again.
content: After going virtual last year, CES, a mega-conference in Las Vegas that’s the traditional launchpad for many of the tech industry’s latest gadgets, is trying to make a comeback. The trade show kicks off on Wednesday, with an estimated 2,200 exhibitors set to show up in person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Barbie and Balmain Want to Make Toys the Next Big Fashion Frontier
description: The first high-fashion collaboration of the year is here, and it’s surprisingly good.
content: It’s the first week of the new year, but the competition to win the 2022 fashion collaboration game, that ever-escalating race to come up with the most eye-popping, head-shaking counterintuitive pairing of brands, has already begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: A Year After Capitol Riot, Trump’s Hold on G.O.P. Is Unrivaled
description: His continued grip on the party shows, once again, that the former president can outlast almost any outrage cycle, no matter how intensely it burns.
content: ​​One year ago, on the very same day when fevered supporters of Donald J. Trump breached the United States Capitol in a violent riot that defiled a symbol of American democracy, the leadership of the Republican National Committee happened to gather, almost 700 miles away at a Ritz-Carlton on Amelia Island, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Austin Mitchell, Chelsea Daniel, Lisa Tobin, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Corey Schreppel
title: Jan. 6, Part 1: ‘The Herd Mentality’
description: Inside an F.B.I. interview with one of the Capitol rioters.
content: Who exactly joined the mob that, almost a year ago, on Jan. 6, breached the walls of the U.S. Capitol in a bid to halt the certification of President Biden’s election victory?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Grace Ashford
title: Hochul Charts New York’s Recovery in First State of State Speech
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul pledged $10 billion to boost the state’s decimated health care work force, proposed a new transit line, and directed funds to combat gun violence.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — In her first State of the State address, Gov. Kathy Hochul on Wednesday outlined her vision for shepherding New York State through its recovery from the coronavirus pandemic, while vowing to open a new chapter of ethical, more transparent government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: The Boy Scouts’ $2.7 Billion Settlement Plan Is at Risk of Failing
description: Of the tens of thousands of victims of sexual abuse who voted on a settlement plan, 73 percent supported it, just below a critical threshold of 75 percent.
content: A $2.7 billion plan to give the Boy Scouts of America a pathway out of bankruptcy while compensating tens of thousands of sex abuse victims was at risk of failing on Wednesday, with more than one-quarter of claimants voting to reject the plan in a preliminary tally of votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: This Vast Wildfire Lab Is Helping Foresters Prepare for a Hotter Planet
description: When the Bootleg fire tore through a nature reserve in Oregon this summer, the destruction varied in different areas. Researchers say forest management methods, including controlled burns, were a big factor.
content: SILVER LAKE, Ore. — When a monster of a wildfire whipped into the Sycan Marsh Preserve here in south-central Oregon in July, Katie Sauerbrey feared the worst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Benjamin Weiser
title: Maxwell Verdict Is Clouded After Juror’s Disclosure of Past Sexual Abuse
description: The revelation, which the juror said figured in the deliberations at Ghislaine Maxwell’s trial, led prosecutors to seek an inquiry and the defense to call for a new trial.
content: Federal prosecutors on Wednesday asked the judge who oversaw Ghislaine Maxwell’s sex-trafficking trial to investigate the process by which one of the jurors was chosen, after he told news outlets he was a sexual abuse victim and had discussed his experience during deliberations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Britain can “ride out” the Covid wave, Boris Johnson says.
content: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain said yesterday that despite the record surge in coronavirus cases, the limited restrictions in England were the right approach and would be maintained.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Skepticism Greets Novak Djokovic’s Vaccine Exemption
description: The world No. 1 received an exemption to a rule that players be vaccinated to play in the Australian Open. Government officials said they had the power to overturn it.
content: Was there ever a doubt that Novak Djokovic, jab or no jab, would end up in Melbourne this month to defend his Australian Open title?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francis Fukuyama
title: One Single Day. That’s All It Took for the World to Look Away From Us.
description: The Jan. 6 attack on Congress marked a significant decline in American global power and influence.
content: The Jan. 6 attack on Congress by a mob inspired by former President Donald Trump marked an ominous precedent for U.S. politics. Not since the Civil War had the country failed to effect a peaceful transfer of power, and no previous candidate purposefully contested an election’s results in the face of broad evidence that it was free and fair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Dr. Ronald Weinstein, Telepathology Pioneer, Dies at 83
description: Decades ago, he demonstrated that cancer could be diagnosed remotely. It was a pivotal step in the evolution of telemedicine.
content: In August 1986, a doctor in Washington, D.C., manipulating a microscope, examined a tissue sample from a breast-cancer patient and correctly diagnosed that her tumor had spread. What was unusual about the diagnosis was that the tissue sample and the microscope were half a country away, in El Paso.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Before Their Marriages Came These Proposals
description: Some of our favorite ways that couples who wed in 2021 said, “Will you marry me?”
content: Marriage stories from around the world continued to fill the Weddings pages of The New York Times in 2021, proving that no force of nature, not even a pandemic, could overwhelm the power of love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Quackenbush
title: In the Australian Outback, an Abandoned Water Tank Quenches the Soul
description: Beneath the skies of a remote mining town, a composer and an architect created a musical chamber for marveling at the universe.
content: Life in Cobar was a delicate thing until the arrival of the Silver Tank. In the vast, red-dirt hinterland of Australia, over 400 miles northwest of the shores of Sydney, rainwater is scarce. ​​For thousands of years, the nomadic Aboriginal Ngiyampaa people excelled at the art of survival by creating natural rock reservoirs. But after European settlers discovered copper and gold in the area in the 1870s, enough water was needed to sustain a booming mining town. Reservoirs were dug. Water was trained in from afar. Then, in 1901, a 33-foot-high steel water tank painted silver, hence its nickname, was erected about a mile outside of town. While the threat of drought remained (and remains to this day), it turned dusty Cobar, a freckle at the edge of the Outback, into something of a desert oasis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Solnit
title: Why Republicans Keep Falling for Trump’s Lies
description: Authoritarians don’t just want to control the government, the economy and the military. They want to control the truth.
content: When called upon to believe that Barack Obama was really born in Kenya, millions got in line. When encouraged to believe that the 2012 Sandy Hook murder of twenty children and six adults was a hoax, too many stepped up. When urged to believe that Hillary Clinton was trafficking children in the basement of a Washington, D.C., pizza parlor with no basement, they bought it, and one of them showed up in the pizza place with a rifle to protect the kids. The fictions fed the frenzies, and the frenzies shaped the crises of 2020 and 2021. The delusions are legion: Secret Democratic cabals of child abusers, millions of undocumented voters, falsehoods about the Covid-19 pandemic and the vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle and Michael Gonchar
title: How Worried Should We Be About Our Democracy?
description: On Jan. 6, 2021, rioters attacked the U.S. Capitol in an attempt to stop the certification of the 2020 presidential election. One year later, is our democracy still in danger?
content: One year ago, as President Trump’s allies in Congress began an effort to disrupt the certification of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory, Mr. Trump gave a speech encouraging his supporters to march to the Capitol. Those supporters then attacked the symbolic building — the seat of the legislative branch — while members of Congress fled for safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: caveat
description: This word has appeared in 177 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed officials discussed raising rates sooner and faster in 2022.
description: Minutes from the Federal Reserve’s December meeting show that officials are contemplating when and how quickly to lift interest rates.
content: Federal Reserve officials suggested that they might withdraw support for the economy more quickly than policymakers had previously expected, minutes from their December meeting showed, as a moment of uncomfortably high inflation forces them to reorient their policy path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Why Isn’t Biden’s Expanded Child Tax Credit More Popular?
description: The expansion has expired, and a bill to renew it has stalled. Public opinion is favorable but not overwhelmingly so, for several reasons.
content: A significant piece of President Biden’s domestic agenda has come to an end. The monthly expansion of the existing child tax credit expired last month after Congress failed to extend it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Favorite Moments in Sports
description: What were the most memorable moments in sports in 2021 for you?
content: The Times has gathered “18 Sports Highlights From 2021 Worth Watching Again,” but before you take a look at our list, we’d love to hear yours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Luke Broadwater
title: A Long, Hard Year for Republicans Who Voted to Impeach After Jan. 6
description: Ten House Republicans voted to charge President Donald J. Trump with inciting the Capitol attack. All of them are still struggling with the consequences.
content: WASHINGTON — The 10 House Republicans who voted to impeach Donald J. Trump did so with the same conviction — that a president of their party deserved to be charged with inciting insurrection on Jan. 6, 2021 — and the same hope — that his role in doing so would finally persuade the G.O.P. to repudiate him.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why the Coming Months Will Be Critical for Biden’s Climate Plan
description: There’s potential political trouble on the horizon for the president.
content: President Biden couldn’t persuade Congress to pass major climate legislation in 2021, and it looks like his plans to slash America’s planet-warming pollution could face an even harder path this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Carl Bernstein, Looking Back at His Start, Conjures the Newsrooms of the Early 1960s
description: “Chasing History” tells the story of his journalistic apprenticeship at The Evening Star in Washington, D.C., when he was in his teens and early 20s.
content: Carl Bernstein’s new book, “Chasing History,” is his second memoir. His first, “Loyalties,” appeared more than three decades ago, in 1989.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: A Georgia woman is sentenced to 3 years over a Covid fraud scheme.
description: The woman, who fraudulently obtained more than $6 million in Covid relief money, is the latest example of Americans misusing the Paycheck Protection Program.
content: A woman in Georgia who fraudulently obtained more than $6 million in Covid relief money was sentenced to more than three years in prison on Tuesday, the Justice Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Using Harsh Language, Macron Issues a Challenge to the Unvaccinated
description: The French president was seeking to tap into a rich political vein: anger among the majority of vaccinated people at a minority who refuse to get vaccinated and disproportionately occupy hospital beds.
content: PARIS — Faced with a surge in coronavirus cases driven by the Omicron variant, President Emmanuel Macron of France said Wednesday that he wanted to “piss off” millions of his citizens who refuse to get vaccinated by squeezing them out of the country’s public spaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paige McClanahan
title: Meet the Woman Who Helped Set a Speed Record on a Classic Alpine Ski Route
description: Valentine Fabre and her ski-mountaineering partner, Hillary Gerardi, took on the Haute Route, traversing 66 miles of glaciers and passes in less than 27 hours. The challenge? Finding confidence.
content: Valentine Fabre has no reason to doubt her abilities in the mountains. The 45-year-old Frenchwoman helped her country earn two world championships in ski mountaineering, a high-adrenaline endurance sport that involves sprinting up and racing down mountains on skis. She’s also a military-trained doctor with a focus on high-mountain medicine, and a resident of the French Alps for 20 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Gowns, Puppets and Sharks: 8 Cultural Sights to See This Winter
description: Cold, dreary weekends are upon us. So what to do with the kids (or yourself, for that matter)? Here are some suggestions, including museums, historic homes and gardens.
content: The holidays are over — the Christmas presents opened, the menorah extinguished, the karamu feast consumed — but the unmerry part of the winter season doesn’t have to be a drag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Dana Goldstein
title: In a Clash With the Teachers’ Union, Chicago Cancels Classes for a Day
description: The labor union, in an effort to force a switch to remote learning, voted to stay home from classrooms on Wednesday. The city responded by calling off instruction altogether.
content: CHICAGO — Public school officials in Chicago canceled classes for Wednesday amid a clash with the teachers’ union, whose members had threatened to stay home in a bid to force instruction online during a coronavirus surge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: The Law of Unintended Political Consequences Strikes Again
description: Progressive philanthropists who fund groups that promote extreme views are “exacerbating intraparty conflict and stoking interparty backlash.”
content: The killing of George Floyd and the nationwide Black Lives Matter protests that followed drove an exceptionally large increase in foundation grants and pledges to criminal and racial justice reform groups and other causes, ranging from the United Negro College Fund to the Center for Antiracist Research and from the National Museum of African American History to the Yes 4 Minneapolis campaign to dismantle the Minneapolis Police Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Just What I’ve Always Wanted
description: In this puzzle from Damon Gulczynski, it all depends on your point of view.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — This puzzle from Damon Gulczynski is just what I’ve always wanted from a Wednesday puzzle — and that’s no 30A! It’s got a neat theme, some juicy fill and clues that are just a tad more challenging than what you’d find in a Monday or Tuesday puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Murray Carpenter
title: Milk Companies Look West, Pressuring Northeast Dairy Farmers
description: Organic milk has been a lifeline for small farms in Maine and other New England states. Now those farms are facing trouble as milk processors look to huge dairies in Western states.
content: SEARSMONT, Maine — Glendon Mehuren II’s Faithful Venture Farm, 35 miles east of the state capital of Augusta, looks as tranquil as the farms pictured on cartons of organic milk. Cows ramble among weathered barns perched on a hill surrounded by small pastures and woodlots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Haigney
title: What Daily Routine Videos Actually Show Us
description: A look into the anxious aspirations of young people.
content: The video is a play-by-play account of what one teenage girl did with her afternoon, segmented into short intervals and performed for the internet. Time stamps flash across the screen: “2:30 tidied up and listened to a podcast.” We watch as a laptop closes and makeup bottles and hair ties appear, neatly organized, on a bureau. “3:15 got ready for my run” — she braids her hair and laces up her sneakers, lip-syncing to upbeat music. At 3:30 she runs; at 4:00 she hydrates, which she illustrates by filling a large Mason jar with water and taking a sip. “4:15 shower” — a montage of gray tiles and silver faucets and bottles of shampoo and conditioner. It goes on like this, through “4:45 reading” (Donna Tartt’s “The Secret History”), “6:00 studying,” “7:00 salad bowl,” “7:30 watched tv with mum,” “8:30 watched greys anatomy,” “10:30 meditation” and, finally, “11:00 went to sleep.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Omicron Is Spreading Rapidly Through California
description: More than 20 percent of coronavirus tests have come back positive over the past week, according to the statewide average.
content: How fast is the coronavirus spreading in California?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Chicago Fights Over In-Person Learning
description: The highly contagious Omicron variant is sowing chaos in schools across the U.S.
content: In our first send of 2022, it feels a little like the beginning of 2021 — in other words, we have a full slate of coronavirus news. First up: brinkmanship in Chicago, as cases surge. And then: Omicron-fueled chaos across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: In a Race to Shape the Future, History Is Under New Pressure
description: A wave of misleading revisionism has become epidemic in both autocracies and democracies. It has been notably effective — and contagious.
content: In Russia, an organization dedicated to remembering Soviet-era abuses faces state-ordered liquidation as the Kremlin imposes a sanitized national history in its place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Put a Female Statue on a Vacant Pedestal? An Italian City Says Not So Fast.
description: In Padua, Italy, a proposal to include a female philosopher in a monument whose 78 sculptures are all men has spurred debate.
content: ROME — Prato della Valle is the largest public square in Italy, with a canal lined with statues surrounding an artificial island where locals love to stroll, or take in the sun on warmer days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: The New Year Begins
description: Let’s hear it for achievable goals.
content: Welcome. I’ve become fixated on the nook, on making it so comfortable and inviting that uninterrupted hours of reading will have no choice but to happen within it. It’s less nook and more corner, a corner where an old wingback chair has been residing for two years. The chair was once part of a guest-friendly tableau, opposite the couch, the coffee table like a campfire between. The living room has been so many other rooms for so long — office, gym, movie theater, Zoom bar, Zoom therapist’s office, Zoom everything else — that it’s forgotten its old remit: Be cozy and inviting, be a place for lavish hanging out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Novak Djokovic Is Refused Entry Into Australia Over Vaccine Exemption
description: The No. 1 men’s tennis player was told to leave the country following a 10-hour standoff with government officials at a Melbourne airport. He remained as he awaited the fate of a legal appeal.
content: Novak Djokovic, the world’s No. 1-ranked men’s tennis player, traveled all day Wednesday from Dubai to Australia, a journey that was supposed to begin his defense of the Australian Open singles championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Luke Broadwater
title: House Panel Asks Sean Hannity of Fox News to Cooperate in Jan. 6 Inquiry
description: The committee told Mr. Hannity it had obtained “dozens of text messages” he exchanged with senior Trump White House officials around the time of the riot.
content: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol has requested that Sean Hannity, the star Fox News host, respond to questions about his communications with former President Donald J. Trump and his staff in the days surrounding the riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Has a Backup Plan for Parents in the Pandemic
description: With the return of remote learning, Colbert says to bring in the mothers-in-law.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Try Canceling Joan Didion
description: An appreciation of the great writer’s conservative origins.
content: If it’s really true, as Michael Wolff reported on Monday for Richard Rushfield’s Hollywood newsletter The Ankler, that Random House will not be releasing a planned compilation of Norman Mailer’s writings on some sort of political-correctness grounds — Mailer’s 1957 essay “The White Negro” was allegedly invoked as a cassus cancellatus — then honestly, I’m a little bit disappointed in cancel culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: How Trump Kept His Grip After Jan. 6
description: Only weeks after instigating the Capitol riot, Donald Trump was back in command of the Republican Party.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the political news in Washington and across the nation. We’re your hosts, Blake and Leah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: England will ease testing rules for travel as Omicron becomes widespread.
description: With the coronavirus variant so prevalent, Britain’s leader said, there is little point in demanding that visitors screen themselves for it.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Wednesday scaled back restrictions on people traveling to England as the Omicron variant appears to be so widespread that measures tightened in November can no longer stem the spread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: OpenSea valued at $13.3 billion in new round of venture funding.
description: The blockchain start-up, one of the most talked about in Silicon Valley, said on Tuesday that had it raised $300 million in new venture capital.
content: OpenSea, one of the most talked-about blockchain start-ups in Silicon Valley, said on Tuesday that it had raised $300 million in new venture capital, making it the latest company to cash in on a rush to fund cryptocurrency start-ups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: With Legislation Stalled, Biden Will Speak in Atlanta on Voting Rights
description: He will be joined by Vice President Kamala Harris, who is leading the administration’s push for voting access.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden will deliver a speech in Atlanta next week that will focus on the urgency of passing voting rights legislation and will condemn a swath of state-level efforts to limit access to the ballot box as an attack on fundamental constitutional rights, the White House announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Lynn
title: Bloomfield, N.J.: A Walkable Suburb With Plenty of Green Space
description: Less than 20 miles from Midtown, the Essex County township appeals to those who want to move out of the city without leaving its conveniences behind.
content: Looking to move out of their apartment in Jersey City after their first child was born, Angelina and Scott Peters scouted communities in nearby Essex County, N.J. The couple fell in love with Montclair. “But it was a little out of our price range,” said Mr. Peters, 43, who works in the back office of a bank. Then they found Bloomfield, just next door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frans de Waal
title: What Role Do Emotions Play in the Way Our Brains Work?
description: In “Emotional,” Leonard Mlodinow examines the effect of feelings on our thought processes and mental lives.
content: EMOTIONALHow Feelings Shape Our ThinkingBy Leonard Mlodinow
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: F.B.I. Arrests Man Accused of Stealing Unpublished Book Manuscripts
description: Filippo Bernardini, an Italian citizen who worked in publishing, was charged with wire fraud and identity theft for a scheme that prosecutors said affected hundreds of people over five or more years.
content: They were perplexing thefts, lacking a clear motive or payoff, and they happened in the genteel, not particularly lucrative world of publishing: Someone was stealing unpublished book manuscripts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Step Aside, LeBron and Dak, and Make Room for Banjo and Kazooie’
description: In this lesson, students will explore how Gen Z has gone from “play ball” to PlayStation, as traditional youth athletics have declined in favor of e-sports. Then, they will profile an athlete who illustrates this trend.
content: Featured Article: “Step Aside, LeBron and Dak, and Make Room for Banjo and Kazooie” by Joe Drape
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Cuomo’s Criminal Sexual Assault Case Is Dropped
description: The woman who said former Gov. Andrew Cuomo groped her was “credible,” the district attorney said, but proving the charge would be a challenge.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at the latest development in the sexual harassment scandal involving former Gov. Andrew Cuomo. We’ll also look at the end of the reign of Coney Island’s unofficial mayor, who says he was fired by an organization he started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel and Ryan Mac
title: Right-Wing Calls to Celebrate Jan. 6 Anniversary Draw a Muted Response
description: Online chatter about holding rallies has grown, but sizable real-world gatherings on Thursday are unlikely to materialize.
content: Last month, a onetime campaign aide to former President Donald J. Trump posted on Facebook, Twitter, Gab and other social media sites. For the first anniversary of the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol, he wrote, candlelight vigils would be held in 20 cities on Thursday to honor those who stormed the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Rabbi Shot in Synagogue Attack Is Sentenced to Prison in Fraud Schemes
description: Yisroel Goldstein, who was wounded in the deadly 2019 attack on the Chabad of Poway synagogue, north of San Diego, was sentenced to 14 months in fraud schemes in which, prosecutors say, he received more than $500,000.
content: A rabbi who was shot and wounded during a deadly attack on his synagogue north of San Diego in 2019 was sentenced on Tuesday to 14 months in prison for engaging in yearslong, multimillion-dollar fraud schemes, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Why More American Children Are Dying by Gunfire
description: Toddlers are discovering guns under piles of clothes and between couch cushions. Teenagers are obtaining untraceable ghost guns made from kits. Middle school students are carrying handguns for protection.
content: Kendall Munson was so worried about the gun violence in her neighborhood on Chicago’s South Side that she sent her sons to live with their grandparents outside Atlanta. But death found them anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
title: Supply Chain Woes Prompt a New Push to Revive U.S. Factories
description: Companies are testing whether the United States can regain some of the manufacturing output it ceded in recent decades to China and other countries.
content: When visitors arrive at the office of America Knits in tiny Swainsboro, Ga., the first thing they see on the wall is a black-and-white photo that a company co-founder, Steve Hawkins, discovered in a local antiques store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Hochul Vows to Lift Economy, Lure Health Workers and Add a Transit Link
description: The proposals, released as part of Ms. Hochul’s first State of the State address, reflected her priorities as she prepares to run for a full term as governor.
content: Hospitals coping with a surge in Covid-19 patients. An economy battered by shutdowns. A housing crisis driving people to homelessness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Relaxing Is a Skill. Here’s How to Do It.
description: Letting the tension flow out of your muscles can improve your physical and mental well-being.
content: Sometime in 2021, I learned how to do something that I suspect will greatly improve how I deal with what already looks to be a harrowing 2022. This thing I learned sounds trivial, a practice so simple you’d think there’d be no need for special instruction — which is probably why a lot of us go through life not knowing that there is a particular technique to getting it right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: CES Tests an Appetite for Live Events
description: Organizers insist that the conference, which formally kicks off today, had to return in-person.
content: After going virtual last year, the Consumer Electronics Show, a mega-conference in Las Vegas that’s the traditional launchpad for many of the tech industry’s latest gadgets, is trying to make a comeback. CES kicks off today, with an estimated 2,200 exhibitors set to show up in person. But with the highly contagious Omicron variant of the coronavirus surging, scores of major tech companies are still presenting mostly virtually.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels and Natalie Proulx
title: How Has Omicron Affected Your School and Community?
description: A new coronavirus variant has sent case counts soaring across the United States. Has it disrupted your life?
content: In a matter of weeks, the highly contagious Omicron variant has driven coronavirus case counts to record levels in the United States, upending air travel, canceling sporting events, reversing return-to-office plans and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: The Boy King of YouTube
description: Ten-year-old Ryan Kaji and his family have turned videos of him playing with toys into a multimillion-dollar empire. Why do so many other kids want to watch?
content: Over the protests of my fellow concerned parents, I want to admit something: I don’t care all that much about screen time, the great child-rearing panic of the 21st century. So many of us have come to believe that if our children spend more than a certain amount of time staring at a screen, whether television, phone or iPad, they will succumb to some capitalist plot to turn them all into little consumption monsters with insatiable appetites for toys, sugar, more screen time. This seems absurd to me, but as the father of a 4-year-old, I have not been immune to screen-time shaming — it upsets me to see my child watching a vapid show like “Paw Patrol” on our iPad. These moments of protest usually come, it should be noted, when I’m sitting beside her, staring at my own phone, scrolling through Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Noah Weiland
title: For C.D.C.’s Walensky, a Steep Learning Curve on Messaging
description: Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, has stumbled in explaining her policy decisions.
content: WASHINGTON — Two days before Christmas, with the Omicron variant driving a near-vertical rise in new coronavirus cases, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention alerted the White House that she planned to recommend that people infected with the virus isolate for five days instead of 10.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Photos from the scene of the Philadelphia fire.
description: It was one of the deadliest residential fires in the city’s recent history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Move Quickly on Jan. 6 Cases, but One Big Question Remains
description: In the year since the assault on the Capitol by a pro-Trump mob, more than 700 people have been arrested, with little public indication from the Justice Department of how high the investigation might reach.
content: By almost any measure, the criminal investigation of the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol is a prosecutorial effort of unparalleled complexity and scope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: They Screamed, We Screamed. Now They’re in ‘Scream’ Again.
description: After more than a decade, Neve Campbell, Courteney Cox and David Arquette return to take a new stab at the meta-horror franchise. They didn’t jump in right away.
content: Twenty-five years after “Scream,” Neve Campbell is still seeing Ghostface everywhere she goes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Stocks Are Great for the Very Young — and the Very Old
description: An economist says that retirees should tilt toward stocks as they age.
content: Conventional investing wisdom says that the older you get, the less of your financial assets should be in the stock market. One frequently heard justification is that stocks rise reliably in the long run but can fluctuate a lot in the short run and that if you’re old, you don’t have time to recover from a bear market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: How to Stop Trump and Prevent Another Jan. 6
description: Drop talk of dismantling the police and taking steps to dismantle the Constitution.
content: On Christmas morning, I woke up early and flipped on CNN, where I found the newscaster toggling among three news stories — two really depressing ones and an amazingly uplifting one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Flávia Milhorance and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Rio Cancels Carnival Street Parties but Keeps Parade
description: As the Omicron variant sweeps the globe, the parties in Rio de Janeiro, which ordinarily draw millions of revelers, have been called off for a second year.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — While Rio de Janeiro’s renowned Carnival parade will go on, the city will cancel its street parties, the mayor said on Tuesday, to the dismay of millions of revelers who pour into the city’s public spaces every year to celebrate and wash away any sorrows in samba, sweat and beer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Karan Deep Singh
title: India’s Rising Omicron Wave Brings a Grim Sense of Déjà Vu
description: Just months after Delta fueled hospital failures and funeral pyres, India’s leaders again offer a mixed message: Their political rallies are packed even as they order curfews and work closures.
content: NEW DELHI — When the Omicron coronavirus variant spread through India late in December, Prime Minister Narendra Modi urged the nation to be vigilant and follow medical guidelines. Arvind Kejriwal, the chief minister of the capital region of Delhi, swiftly introduced night curfews, shut down movie theaters, and slashed restaurants and public transport to half capacity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Grammy Awards Postponed Amid Covid-19 Surge
description: The Recording Academy has not announced a new date for its 64th annual show, originally scheduled for Jan. 31 in Los Angeles.
content: For the second year in a row, the Grammy Awards have been pushed back by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Audie Cornish, host of ‘All Things Considered,’ is leaving NPR.
description: Her decision follows the recent exits of other prominent people of color at the public broadcaster.
content: Audie Cornish, a host of NPR’s “All Things Considered,” is leaving her job, becoming the latest prominent person of color to leave the public broadcaster.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Mezzo-Sopranos
description: Listen to the warm, rich sound of Marilyn Horne, Janet Baker, Grace Bumbry and more.
content: In the past we’ve chosen the five minutes or so we would play to make our friends fall in love with classical music, piano, opera, cello, Mozart, 21st-century composers, violin, Baroque music, sopranos, Beethoven, flute, string quartets, tenors, Brahms, choral music, percussion, symphonies, Stravinsky, trumpet, Maria Callas, Bach and the organ.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: Reign of Coney Island’s ‘Mayor’ Ends in a Sideshow by the Sea
description: Dick Zigun, who spent decades restoring the Brooklyn enclave to its carnivalesque glory, is forced out of the organization he helped create.
content: When Dick Zigun set his sights on Coney Island in the late 1970s, the seaside section of Brooklyn was, like much of the rest of New York, at a low ebb. Yet he saw magic in the beach, boardwalk, rides and arcades that had long defined the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Says It Tested a Hypersonic Missile
description: It was the latest in a series of tests the North has conducted this fall.
content: SEOUL — North Korea launched a ballistic missile off its east coast on Wednesday, the South Korean military said, days after the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, said his country should focus on bolstering food production in the new year while continuing to strengthen its military power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Rosenberg
title: For Karla Knight, Paranormal Is Normal
description: An interview with the mystically inclined artist, who shares the interests of Hilma af Klint and Agnes Pelton.
content: RIDGEFIELD, Conn. — Artists attuned to the supernatural, paranormal and occult have sometimes been dismissed as eccentric visionaries, but the art world is increasingly receptive to their channelings. An immensely popular retrospective of the Swedish mystic Hilma af Klint, at the Guggenheim in New York three years ago, connected early Modernist abstraction to Spiritualist séances; last year, the Whitney celebrated the Transcendental symbolism of Agnes Pelton, who painted luminous portals and apparitions within desert landscapes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: PG&E equipment is blamed for starting the Dixie Fire in Northern California.
description: Fire investigators referred their findings to prosecutors.
content: California fire investigators on Tuesday pinned the blame for the Dixie Fire — the second-largest blaze in the state’s history — on equipment owned by Pacific Gas & Electric and referred the case to prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: These Are the People Who Died in Connection With the Capitol Riot
description: A bipartisan Senate report found that at least seven people had lost their lives in connection with the Jan. 6 attack.
content: WASHINGTON — As a pro-Trump protest turned into a violent attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6 last year, four people in the crowd died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: YIVO Institute Makes Archives of Yiddish Life Available Online
description: After a lengthy effort, artifacts from collections in Lithuania and New York that document Yiddish culture in Eastern Europe before World War II will be accessible to scholars and others.
content: Almost 100 years ago, a group of Jewish linguists and historians decided to create a “scientific institute” that would collect literary manuscripts, letters, theater posters, business records and ephemera so they could document the flourishing Yiddish culture of Eastern Europe and promote the language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Mini-Vows Submission Form: Apply Here to Have Your Wedding Featured
description: You may also have questions about how this process works. We have answers.
content: Thank you for your interest in having your wedding featured in The New York Times. We are actively seeking couples with interesting, inspiring and diverse love stories that represent and reflect the world around us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia-Allied Forces to Intervene as Unrest Sweeps Kazakhstan
description: The Kazakh president requested the peacekeeping troops as an uprising, sparked by a gas price increase in the resource-rich Central Asian nation, headed toward a fifth day.
content: MOSCOW — A Russian-led military alliance said late Wednesday that it would send peacekeeping forces to Kazakhstan at the invitation of the country’s president to help put down a growing protest movement there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Adrienne Adams, First Black Council Speaker, Wants to Rebuild New York
description: Ms. Adams, who became speaker on Wednesday, will lead the most diverse City Council ever as New York tries to recover from the pandemic. She already faces battles with the mayor.
content: Adrienne Adams had to overcome several obstacles on her way to being voted in on Wednesday as the first Black woman to serve as speaker of the New York City Council, the second-most-powerful position in city government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Will We Go From Pandemic to Recession?
description: Inflation unchecked can become a father to extremism.
content: The scariest story I read over the holidays had nothing to do with winter wildfires, the Covid-flu combo or the threat of Russia invading Ukraine. It was Christopher Leonard’s superb profile in Politico of Thomas Hoenig, a retired central banker. Hoenig made a name for himself after the financial crisis of 2008, as one of the top members of the Federal Reserve who wouldn’t go along with then-Chairman Ben Bernanke’s efforts to float the economy on an ocean of money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Plows, Donna Schou and Natalie Proulx
title: Photographing Interesting People in Your Community: A Guide to Taking Portraits
description: Follow these five steps to learn how to take photos that capture your subject’s background and personality.
content: What can a photograph reveal about someone’s personality, background, work, hobbies or passions?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: The Oscars Want Crowd-Pleasers, but Where Are the Crowds?
description: As contenders like “West Side Story” and “Belfast” struggle for audiences, can a blockbuster like “Spider-Man: No Way Home” swing into the Oscar race?
content: After last year’s Oscar ceremony honored a group of small, challenging movies and tanked in the ratings, you can bet that this year, the academy is eager to nominate films that audiences can get excited about. Indeed, this year’s crop of awards movies includes several old-fashioned crowd-pleasers to choose from.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Slate’s Top Editor Leaves After a Three-Year Run
description: Jared Hohlt, who made his reputation at New York magazine, led the publication’s newsroom during a difficult period for digital media.
content: After nearly three years as the editor in chief of Slate, the online publication and podcasting platform, Jared Hohlt is stepping down, a spokeswoman for the site said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Reimbursement for rapid at-home tests will start next week, a White House official says.
description: With demand for coronavirus tests exploding, new federal sites will open soon, the White House said, but there were no details yet on when Americans would get the free tests President Biden promised.
content: President Biden’s coronavirus response coordinator said Wednesday that, beginning next week, Americans struggling to get tested for the coronavirus will be able to have the cost of rapid at-home tests reimbursed by their insurers, but offered no specific promises about when free tests would be available.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Emily Anthes
title: Being ‘Up to Date’ on Covid Vaccine Now Includes a Booster, C.D.C. Says
description: The agency did not change the definition of what qualifies as full vaccination — a subject of intense interest to many.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Wednesday said it was not changing its definition of “full vaccination” against the coronavirus. But the agency changed its emphasis on the appropriate regimen, tweaking how it referred to the shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: A variant found in France is not a concern, the W.H.O. says.
description: The so-called I.H.U. variant contains numerous mutations of the coronavirus, but experts say it has shown little sign of spreading so far.
content: The World Health Organization says that it is monitoring a coronavirus variant detected in a small number of patients in France, but that, for now, there is little reason to worry about its spread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.3 Million Homes in Maine, New Mexico and New York
description: A Colonial Revival home in Cape Elizabeth, a desert house in Taos and an 1880 Victorian in Greenport.
content: Frederick Augustus Tompson, a local architect, designed many of the grandest public buildings and homes in Portland, Maine, in the late 19th and early 20th century, as the city rebuilt after an 1866 fire that destroyed nearly 2,000 structures. He also designed this house in Cape Elizabeth, a nearby town. During renovations, the sellers discovered Mr. Tompson’s original blueprints and stylebook for the house, and most of the original woodwork and many original light fixtures remained intact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: William M. Ellinghaus Dies at 99; Presided Over AT&T Breakup
description: He led the communications giant when it settled an antitrust suit in the 1980s, not long after he helped save New York City in the fiscal crisis of the ’70s.
content: William M. Ellinghaus, who as president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the world’s largest corporation, helped preside over its breakup in the early 1980s — and who a few years earlier had been instrumental in saving New York City from default — died on Tuesday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Sony takes a step toward the electric car market with a new subsidiary.
description: Japan’s electronics giant introduced a new version of a prototype S.U.V. that runs on batteries.
content: TOKYO — Sony announced on Tuesday that it was establishing a subsidiary devoted to transportation, taking it a step closer to entering the fiercely competitive electric car market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Tanier
title: This Is the N.F.L. Season That Ran Too Long
description: The N.F.L.’s final-week schedule usually builds to a Sunday night crescendo. But with only one true elimination game, Week 18’s bloat should feel anticlimactic.
content: Welcome to Week 18 of the N.F.L. season, the superfluous coda to an already-grueling marathon that few besides the television networks and advertisers really wanted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green and Maya Phillips
title: Welcoming Back Live Theater Doesn’t Mean Agreeing About All of It
description: Two critics on the joys (and pains) of a tentatively hopeful fall season.
content: The year that just ended was a difficult one for people who make theater, as they faced economic, aesthetic and medical challenges. In a smaller way it was therefore a strange year for those of us who write about and review their work. Not until late summer 2020 — and then more fully in the fall — did we see live plays and musicals, and enjoy the pleasures that come with doing so: not just the communal experience in the theater but also the shared reflection afterward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Health Risks of Smoke and Ozone Rise in the West as Wildfires Worsen
description: Simultaneous high levels of the two pollutants, which harm human health, are occurring with increasing frequency, researchers say.
content: Dangerous levels of two air pollutants, ozone and smoke, are occurring in tandem with increasing frequency over widespread parts of the Western United States where millions of people live, researchers said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Chicago, Capitol Riot, ‘Scream’: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Billy Turner, Trainer of a Triple Crown Winner, Dies at 81
description: In 1977, under his guidance, Seattle Slew became only the 10th thoroughbred in history to win the Kentucky Derby, Preakness Stakes and Belmont Stakes.
content: Billy Turner, the trainer of Seattle Slew, the 10th thoroughbred to win horse racing’s Triple Crown, died on Friday in hospice care at his home in Reddick, Fla. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: As Beijing Takes Control, Chinese Tech Companies Lose Jobs and Hope
description: The crackdown is killing the entrepreneurial drive that made China a tech power and destroying jobs that used to attract the country’s brightest.
content: Like many ambitious young Chinese, Zhao Junfeng studied hard in college and graduate school so he could land a coveted job as a programmer at a big Chinese internet company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Omicron Is Milder
description: How should that affect your behavior?
content: The details of the Omicron variant are becoming clearer, and they are encouraging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: One Year Later, Assault Still Casts a Pall Over the Capitol and Its Occupants
description: The attempt by a violent mob to interfere with a basic democratic task has left a stain on the institution and a strain on relationships.
content: WASHINGTON — Metal detectors screen lawmakers for weapons at the doors of the House chamber. Staff members are frightened to come to work. Anxious police officers worry about a future attack, even as they relive the one that took place. The citadel of democracy is almost inaccessible to the public it is supposed to welcome and serve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: The C.D.C. Is Hoping You’ll Figure Covid Out on Your Own
description: The government’s haphazard and disorganized response to Omicron doesn’t bode well.
content: I have some good news and some bad news, and they’re both the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Mary Alice Thatch, Publisher Who Won Pardon for the Wilmington 10, Dies at 78
description: At the helm of The Wilmington Journal, she pushed to cover issues affecting the Black community that had been ignored by the mainstream press.
content: Mary Alice Thatch, a crusading, third-generation newspaper publisher in North Carolina who led the fight to exonerate 10 civil rights activists wrongly convicted of arson in the 1970s, died on Dec. 28 at a hospital in Durham, N.C. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Rebecca Robbins
title: Biden Administration to Increase Supply of ‘Game Changer’ Pfizer Pill
description: President Biden announced that his administration would double its order of Pfizer’s scarce Covid-19 antiviral drug, which has been shown to reduce hospitalizations.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States government doubled its order for Pfizer’s Covid pills on Tuesday, a move that will modestly increase the nation’s very limited supply of the treatment in the short term amid a record-setting surge in coronavirus cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Interview, Edit and Shape: A Step-by-Step Guide to Participating in Our Profile Contest
description: Advice from Times journalists and mentor texts for every step of the process — plus short, practical exercises to try along the way.
content: Are you taking part in our new profile contest that invites teenagers anywhere in the world to choose an interesting person in their community to research, interview, photograph and write about?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: The Tech That Will Invade Our Lives in 2022
description: Here we go again: Virtual reality, now called “the metaverse,” will be a thing. So will the smart home.
content: Each year, I look ahead at what’s new in consumer technology to guide you through what you might expect to buy — and what will most likely be a fad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Revolt in Kazakhstan: What’s Happening, and Why It Matters
description: As protests in the oil-rich Central Asian country gain momentum, the events threaten to reverberate across the region.
content: Thousands of angry protesters have taken to the streets of Kazakhstan in recent days, the biggest crisis to shake the autocratic country in decades. The events are a stark challenge to President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev less than three years into his rule and are destabilizing an already volatile region where Russia and the United States compete for influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: German Start-Ups Lay the Groundwork for a Marijuana Bonanza
description: Two of the three parties in Germany’s new governing coalition support legalization, a potentially radical shift in the conservative country.
content: FRANKFURT — The first sign that something is different about the centuries-old former winery in a sleepy hillside German village surrounded by grape vines is the door leading to the estate. It is brand-new and reinforced with a steel grate. Behind it, a start-up has built a multimillion-dollar testing and processing facility, getting ready to cash in on Germany’s next big wave: the possible legalization of marijuana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Kazakhstan Declares State of Emergency as Protests Over Fuel Prices Spread
description: Thousands took to the street as gas prices doubled. The government responded with curfews and tear gas. The president later announced the resignation of the government.
content: MOSCOW — The president of Kazakhstan declared a two-week state of emergency in two regions of the Central Asian country early Wednesday after nationwide protests erupted over rising fuel prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kat Eschner
title: The Promises and Perils of Psychedelic Health Care
description: Many recreational drugs known for mind-altering trips are being studied to treat depression, substance use and other disorders. Here’s what you need to know.
content: Oregon is legalizing mushrooms. Ketamine can be delivered to your home. People are microdosing LSD to treat pandemic-related anxiety and Wall Street is pouring billions into companies that sell mind-altering drugs. It seems like psychedelics — though mostly still illegal — are everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: How ‘Muscle Memory’ May Help Us Get in Shape
description: Muscles develop a lasting molecular “memory” of past resistance exercises that helps them bounce back from long periods of inactivity.
content: After two years of Covid-19 and its disruptions to our exercise routines, many of us may feel like we have forgotten how to be fit. But an encouraging new study suggests that our muscles remember. The study involved mice, but it builds on similar experiments with weight training and people. It found that muscles developed a pervasive and lasting molecular “memory” of past resistance exercises that helped them bounce back quickly from long layoffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Christine Chung
title: How to Stay Safe if You’re Trapped in Your Car During a Snowstorm
description: Safety experts offer advice on how people can keep warm and collected if they are stranded for hours on the road. Their top tip? Be prepared.
content: A snowstorm in Virginia stranded hundreds of drivers on Interstate 95 this week, leaving them shivering hour after hour, wondering why they couldn’t move and when help was coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Fierce Windstorms Batter Alaska as Thousands Lose Power
description: Tens of thousands of people lost electricity this week, while the wind chill dipped to 35 degrees below zero.
content: After relentless windstorms battered parts of Alaska with gusts of up to 88 miles per hour, making subzero temperatures feel even colder as the winds caused power outages for tens of thousands of people, crews were working on Wednesday to restore service to homes that were left without heating for days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump Cancels Jan. 6 Event, After Allies See It as a Distraction
description: A Mar-a-Lago news conference on the anniversary of the assault on the Capitol struck Republicans, including some advisers to the former president, as a bad idea.
content: Donald J. Trump on Tuesday abruptly canceled a news conference that he had scheduled at his Mar-a-Lago resort for Thursday evening on the one-year anniversary of the breaching of the United States Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Olympic Officials Deflect Calls To Press China on Forced Labor
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 5, 2022.
content: “There’s part of me that thinks they don’t want to offend Beijing anymore.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jimmy Carter
title: Jimmy Carter: I Fear for Our Democracy
description: Even established democracies can fall to military juntas and despots. We can’t let that happen here.
content: One year ago, a violent mob, guided by unscrupulous politicians, stormed the Capitol and almost succeeded in preventing the democratic transfer of power. All four of us former presidents condemned their actions and affirmed the legitimacy of the 2020 election. There followed a brief hope that the insurrection would shock the nation into addressing the toxic polarization that threatens our democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: American Democracy: A Status Check
description: A year after the Jan. 6 insurrection, what have we learned?
content: Just how much trouble is American democracy in? When we look to 2024, it’s easy to focus on the doomsday scenario: an election where legitimate results get thrown out. But our democracy has been eroding for years — and we’ve never been an equal democracy for everyone in the first place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kaminer
title: House Hunting in Israel: An Inventive Use of Concrete Outside of Tel Aviv
description: Despite cooling off early in the pandemic, Israel’s housing market has ‘kept up its momentum,’ thanks to surging demand and lagging supply.
content: Cast in concrete with wood, glass and aluminum accents, this five-bedroom house just south of Tel Aviv, in central Israel, was designed by modernist architects Israelevitz for an Israeli cement-company executive and his family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorie Greenspan
title: This Cake Is a Taste of a Vanishing New York
description: Dorie Greenspan’s poppy-seed cake is a call back to her childhood and shops that are mostly gone.
content: My mother was convinced that baking genes skipped generations. After all, her mother was an excellent baker, she herself baked not at all and I baked all the time. I wish I’d known my grandmother as a baker, but I didn’t show interest in the craft early enough to learn at her elbow. I’ve got only one memory of her in the kitchen: She’s leaning over a small enamel-topped table, it’s covered with a thin cloth and she’s rolling out dough. What I remember most is watching her roll the dough up and around the pin, lift it high, shower the cloth with flour and then return the dough to the table. When she spun the pin and unfurled the dough, it rippled like silk and seemed like a magic trick to me — it still does, even when I do it myself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhonda Garelick
title: Middle Age Doesn’t Happen ‘Just Like That’
description: Why is the “Sex and the City” reboot populated by adults who seem perplexed by everything from politics to their own bodies?
content: Have you heard? There’s a TV show featuring 50-somethings on HBO, right now. “And Just Like That,” the reboot of “Sex and the City,” has resurrected the old gang (Carrie, Miranda and Charlotte — minus Samantha) in present-day New York City, 17 years after the last episode aired. Yes, it turns out that people — even women-people — can actually keep existing beyond the age of 38. Incredible!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Capitol Police Chief Commits to Security Improvements
description: Chief J. Thomas Manger, the head of an agency still reeling from the Jan. 6 attack, told lawmakers he was already addressing most of the 103 recommendations from an internal watchdog.
content: WASHINGTON — With officers still reeling from the mob violence that overran Congress a year ago, the chief of the U.S. Capitol Police told lawmakers on Wednesday that his department was taking steps to address deficiencies laid bare by the attack and would implement more than 100 recommendations for improvement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Hedgehogs Are a Source of Drug-Resistant Bacteria, Study Finds
description: Scientists chart how a battle between fungus and bacteria living on the skin of hedgehogs led to the emergence of a strain of MRSA that can infect cows and humans.
content: The tiny, spiny and adorable hedgehog is helping to upend conventional wisdom about the origins of drug-resistant bacterial infections that kill thousands of people each year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Meaning of Apple at $3 Trillion
description: We aren’t buying more smartphones. So how is this smartphone company making crazy money?
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren
title: 17 Charged as Brooklyn Gang Alliance Is Linked to 4 Deadly Shootings
description: Those charged, ranging in age from 17 to 23, were accused of unleashing a wave of violence that also left 10 other people wounded by gunfire.
content: Seventeen teenagers and young adults who the authorities say belonged to three street gangs that formed an alliance in Brooklyn were charged on Tuesday with unleashing a wave of violence that left four people dead and 10 others wounded in shootings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Can Adams Rebuild, and Rein In, a Notorious N.Y.P.D. Unit?
description: Mayor Eric Adams wants to recreate the department’s plainclothes anti-crime unit, which recovered illegal guns but was responsible for a number of fatal shootings.
content: During his successful campaign for mayor of New York City, Eric Adams made his top priority clear: tackling the rise in gun violence that began early in the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and John Yoon
title: Hong Kong suspends flights from eight countries, including the U.S.
description: The new measures will deepen the city’s isolation and mark a return to the tough restrictions from the early days of the pandemic, as officials race to contain the Omicron variant.
content: Hong Kong announced a series of strict pandemic control measures on Wednesday, including suspending flights from the United States and seven other countries, as it scrambled to contain an incipient coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Quentin Tarantino plans to sell ‘Pulp Fiction’ NFTs, defying a Miramax suit.
description: The director’s fight over ownership of the movie’s script could set a legal precedent for intellectual property rights.
content: When Quentin Tarantino and the movie studio Miramax agreed on the rights to “Pulp Fiction” in the early 1990s, cryptocurrency didn’t exist. Now, Mr. Tarantino is courting controversy — with a crypto twist — over ownership of the cult movie’s script that could set a legal precedent for intellectual property rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Britain Extends Pardons Policy for Consensual Same-Sex Partners
description: The government’s action expands earlier legislative efforts, but for some gay people it is too little, too late. “It impacted me my whole life,” one man said of his conviction.
content: LONDON — A four-decade-old conviction has haunted Terry Stewart, a 68-year-old former social worker, throughout his adult life. Classified as a sexual offense, it came up when he applied for a mortgage or a job, and it stymied memberships to some social organizations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cynthia Miller-Idriss
title: America’s Most Urgent Threat Now Comes From Within
description: The United States needs a public health approach to effectively counter mainstream domestic extremism.
content: For many Americans, the events of Jan. 6 brought the issue of domestic violent extremism to the fore. Through livestreamed images, they watched as attackers equipped with zip ties and bear spray wielded flagpoles and fire extinguishers, pushed through barricades, smashed windows and called for the deaths of elected officials while gallivanting through the halls of Congress. Gallows were constructed outside. Pipe bombs were planted near the headquarters of the Democratic and Republican National Committees. At least seven people died. More catastrophic violence was narrowly averted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: ‘The N.F.L. Is Another No-Good Entity’
description: Eric Dickerson talks about why some former players hate the N.F.L., his assumption that he has C.T.E., and why his single-season rushing record isn’t his most unbreakable.
content: The running backs in today’s N.F.L., Eric Dickerson said, are fine. But none — not Jonathan Taylor, not Ezekiel Elliott, not Derrick Henry — remind him of himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Expecting or Planning? There’s Nothing Magic About Age 35.
description: Prenatal and postpartum care is organized around an outdated definition of “advanced maternal age.”
content: Many of the decisions I made around my pregnancies were based on the looming specter of “advanced maternal age,” which is typically defined as 35 or older. Rudely, this used to be called a “geriatric pregnancy,” but that term is thankfully now out of fashion. In my head, my 35th birthday was some kind of Cinderella clock, but instead of my coach turning back into a pumpkin, it had me imagining that my eggs would shrivel up and die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Variant Déjà Vu in India
description: Doctor shortages, surging cases and mixed messaging.
content: Just a few months ago, as government leaders vastly underestimated the dangers and publicly flouted official advice, the Delta variant ravaged India. Now, with the rise of Omicron, the mixed signals from the government and rapid spread through cities are fueling a sense of déjà vu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: HBO Max and HBO hit 73.8 million subscribers, topping company forecasts.
description: The announcement represents a vindication of the strategy to release the entire Warner Bros. 2021 film slate simultaneously in theaters and on streaming.
content: The streaming service HBO Max and the cable channel HBO ended 2021 with a combined 73.8 million global subscribers, beating year-end projections of 73 million, the platforms’ parent company, AT&T, said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What It’s Like to Be a Teenager Now: The Winners of Our Coming of Age in 2021 Contest
description: 25 videos, comics, poems, paintings, photos, songs, games and GIFs tell a powerful story.
content: In December, the United States surgeon general warned that young people today are facing “devastating” mental health issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: The Devils You Know: Three ‘Spider-Man’ Villains Return in ‘No Way Home’
description: Willem Dafoe, Alfred Molina and Jamie Foxx talk about reprising their bad-guy roles in the blockbuster sequel.
content: They were very good at being bad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Yan Zhuang
title: Skepticism and anger greet Novak Djokovic’s vaccine exemption.
description: Some Australians reacted with fury at the announcement from the world’s No. 1 male tennis player, the sport’s most prominent vaccination skeptic.
content: The news that Novak Djokovic had received a medical exemption to play in the Australian Open tournament this month in Melbourne spurred a range of reactions in Australia, where some politicians and tennis officials called on him to explain himself.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tracking Coronavirus in South Africa: Latest Case Count
description: See the latest charts of coronavirus cases, deaths and vaccinations in South Africa.
content: See the latest charts of coronavirus cases, deaths and vaccinations in South Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Morello
title: Class Struggle in My Family’s Hometown
description: I loved my summers in Marseilles, Ill. But things there have not always been as idyllic as they seemed.
content: I loved my summers in Marseilles, Ill. But things there have not always been as idyllic as they seemed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Jennings
title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Blowing the Fuse’ and More
description: I’m a senior staff editor on The Times’s Features Print Hub. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
content: I’m a senior staff editor on The Times’s Features Print Hub. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

title: The Year in Illustration
description: The New York Times’s most memorable illustrations of 2021
content: The New York Times’s most memorable illustrations of 2021

title: Living In ... Bloomfield, N.J.
description: Less than 20 miles from Midtown, the Essex County township appeals to those who want to move out of the city without leaving its conveniences behind.
content: Less than 20 miles from Midtown, the Essex County township appeals to those who want to move out of the city without leaving its conveniences behind.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1.3 Million
description: A Colonial Revival home in Cape Elizabeth, Maine; a desert house in Taos, N.M.; and an 1880 Victorian in Greenport, N.Y.
content: A Colonial Revival home in Cape Elizabeth, Maine; a desert house in Taos, N.M.; and an 1880 Victorian in Greenport, N.Y.

title: Clean Concrete Contours Near Tel Aviv
description: This modern five-bedroom house outside of Tel Aviv, Israel, is on the market for $3.85 million.
content: This modern five-bedroom house outside of Tel Aviv, Israel, is on the market for $3.85 million.

author: By The New York Times
title: Capitol Police Chief Pledges to Strengthen Security
description: J. Thomas Manger, the chief of the U.S. Capitol Police, told the Senate Rules Committee that the agency would put in place more than 100 recommendations for improvement made by its inspector general in the wake of the Capitol attack.
content: J. Thomas Manger, the chief of the U.S. Capitol Police, told the Senate Rules Committee that the agency would put in place more than 100 recommendations for improvement made by its inspector general in the wake of the Capitol attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Garland Reaffirms Justice Dept.’s Commitment to Jan. 6 Inquiry
description: In remarks delivered one day before the first anniversary of the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland emphasized a commitment to the rule of law and to following the facts wherever they lead.
content: In remarks delivered one day before the first anniversary of the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland emphasized a commitment to the rule of law and to following the facts wherever they lead.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 5, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 5, 2022.
content: An article on Tuesday about an inquiry into a large Colorado wildfire misstated when the fire began. It started on Dec. 30, not just before Christmas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: The Tofu Miracle
description: Master a technique for oven-frying tofu, and adapt it every which way for limitless dinners.
content: Good morning. I’ve been digging Jenny Rosenstrach’s new cookbook, “The Weekday Vegetarians,” and I’m not the only one. Melissa Clark picked up a cool technique for oven-frying tofu from it, and developed an excellent new recipe for crispy tofu with balsamic tomatoes (above). I think that would make a fine dinner this week. Will you give it a try?
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Year After Jan. 6: ‘Democracy Is at Risk’
description: Readers worry about the future of our Republic.
content: To the Editor:
